question:
Consider the following string variable in Python:
text = "Intro to strings"
query: Which of the following statements are false:

options.option: a: text(0) will give the output as 'I'
b: text[5] will give the output as 't'
c: text[-1] will give the output as g
d: text[9]='S' will replace 's' with 'S' in the string text

description.A: This is an error, [] braces are used to refer the index of a string
description.B: The spaces are also counted in the index. The output will be '  ' (blank), text[6] will print 't'
description.C: Negative indices can be used to refer the string in reverse order. Last element being at -1. Hence text [-1] prints 's'. text[-2] will print 'g'
description.D: Strings are immutable and cannot be changed, assignment does not work with string objects.
description.E: text[10] == text [-6] =='t', the 'Not' of the statements returns 'false'
description.F:
len(text) = 16. Hence the LHS expression becomes16-2*2**2 -> 16-2*4 -> 16-8 -> 8, hence LHS is 'True',
text [-13] == 'r' , hence RHS Expression text [-13] != 'r' is 'False'
'True or False' returns 'True'.

question:
Assume, string1 = "Infosys Limited" , string2 = "Mysore". Match the following Python statements with their corresponding
output:

description.option: string1[:4] will slice the string "Infosys Limited" starting from first character (index - 0) i.e. 'I', up to but not including the character at index 4,  i.e. 's'. Hence, Output: 'Into'
Negative Index is used to represent the string from the end. '-1' represents the last character, hence string1[-1] represents 'd'
'*' is a used to concatenate multiple copies of the same string. string1 * 2 concatenates string1 two times.

string1[:-1] slices the string1 from start of the string upto but not including the character at index -1, gives the output as 'Infosys Limite' . string2 is 'Mysore'. Hence the concatenated output is 'Infosys LimiteMysoreInfosys Limite'.
The character at index 1 in string2 i.e. 'Mysore' is 'y'.
The character at index 4 in string2 i.e. 'Mysore' is 'r'.

string1 * 2 gives the output as 'Infosys LimitedInfosys Limited'. string1[:-1] slices the string1 from start of the string upto but not including the character at index -1, gives the output as 'Infosys Limite' . string2 is 'Mysore', hence the concatenated output is 'Infosys LimitedInfosys LimitedInfosys LimiteMysore'

question:
Consider the following string variable in Python:
text ="I love Python"
query: Which of the following will give an output as "Python" (Multiple options can be correct):

description.A: This will slice the string, starting from character at 7th position i.e. 'P' in the string, up to but not including the character at position 13th,  i.e. 'n'. Output: 'Python'
description.B: This will slice the string, starting from character at 8th position i.e. 'y' in the string, up to but not including the character at position 13th,  i.e. 'n'. This will give the output as "ython"
description.C: This will slice the string, starting from character at 7th position i.e. 'P' in the string, up to the end of the String.Output: 'Python'
description.D: In negative indices, the counting starts from the end of the string (with an index of -1) instead of at the beginning. Hence 'n' is -1, 'o' Is -2 and so on. text[-6:-1] will slice the string, starting from character at -6th position "P" till one character before index -1 i.e. 'o', hence output is "Pytho".
description.E: This will slice the string, starting from character at -6th position i.e. 'P' in the string, up to the end of the String. Output: 'Python'

question:
Consider the following string variable and predict which of the following output are true:
message = "Earth is round"

description.A: message[0:6] will slice the given string starting from character at 0th position i.e. 'E' in the string, up to but not including the character at position 6th,  i.e. 'i'.  Hence results in 'Earth ' (observe a space after 'Earth')
description.B: message[9: -1] will slice the given string starting from 9th position i.e. 'r' in the string, up to but not including the character at -1 position i.e. 'd'(a string can be accessed using negative indices, last character having the index -1). Hence results in "roun"
description.C:
message[-5:] will slice the string starting from index -5 i.e. 'r' till the end of the string. Hence results in "round"
message[9:] will slice the staring starting from index 9 (again 'r') till the end of string, hence it also results in "round"
description.D: message[-6:3] will slice the string starting from index -6 i.e. space(" ") till index 3 i.e. 't'. As the ending index comes before the starting index, nothing will be printed. Try executing message[-6:13] and observe the output.

question:
Assume a tuple,
t = (9,8,7,6,5,4)
query:
Which of the following are not allowed/have an error?
1) print(t[4])
2) print(t[6])
3) print(max(t))
4) print(len(t))
5) print(t[2:6])
6) t[5]=3

description.B:
Line 5: Slicing works fine for tuples , output is (7, 6, 5, 4).
Line 6: Type Error as tuples are immutable.
description.C:
Line 3: Prints the maximum number i.e. 9.
Line 4: Prints the length of tuple i.e. 6.
description.D:
Line 2: Index out of range.
Line 6: Type Error as tuples are immutable.

question:
Assume,
tupleA = (46,43,78,32,45,33,65,89)
query:
Expected output is:
46
78
45
65
Choose the code snippets from the options below, to print the expected output.(Multiple options can be correct)

options.option:
a: for i in range(0, len(tupleA), 2):
print(tupleA[i])

b: for i in tupleA:
if(i%2 == 0):
print(i)

c: for i in range(-8, -1, 2):
print(tupleA[i])

d: for i in range(-7, -1, 2):
print(tupleA[i])

description.A: The 'for' loop here is equivalent to 'for i in range(0,8,2)'  for i in (0,2,4,6). 'print(tupleA[i])' prints the elements of 'tupleA' at indices 0,2,4,6, hence the output.
description.B:
The 'for' loop iterates through all the elements of 'tupleA'. The 'if' loop checks if the element is divisible by 2. If yes, it is displayed. Hence the output is:
46
78
32
description.C:
The elements of a tuple can be accessed using negative indices. The last element starts from index '-1'. Hence the element at index '-8' is '46'. The 'for' loop is equivalent to 'for i in(-8,-6,-4,-2)' , hence prints the elements at these indices, the output is:
46
78
45
65
description.D:
The elements of a tuple can be accessed using negative indices and the last element starts from index '-1'. Hence the element at index '-7' is '43'. Think again and answer. This 'for' loop will give the output as:
43
32
33

question: Consider the sets:

Find the output of the following Python code snippet:
s1 = set("my name is John and John is my name".split())

description.A: Try to execute the code and observe the output.
description.B: 'split()' function splits the string into a list of words. 'set()' function removes the duplicate entries from the list and converts it into a set.
description.C: Here 's1' is not a set (Observe the braces). Try again.
description.D: Observe the duplicate values here. Can a set contain duplicate values? Try again.
